content: The "Catastrophic Wildfire Prevention Act of 2012" includes sections on short title, purposes, definitions, authorized projects, public review, administrative review, and species designations. The Act aims to prevent catastrophic wildfires. The "Catastrophic Wildfire Prevention Act of 2012" aims to expedite wildfire prevention projects on Federal lands, reduce threats to endangered species, and provide efficiency tools to streamline projects for reducing wildfires. The "Catastrophic Wildfire Prevention Act of 2012" defines terms like "at-risk community" and "at-risk forest" to address high wildfire risk on Federal lands. The "Catastrophic Wildfire Prevention Act of 2012" defines terms like "at-risk community" and "at-risk forest" to address high wildfire risk on Federal lands, including the loss of key ecosystems, wildlife, or habitats to wildfire. It also includes Federal land in condition class II or III as defined by the Forest Service Rocky Mountain Research Station. The Forest Service Rocky Mountain Research Station developed classes for wildfire prevention projects in at-risk forests or endangered species habitats. These projects aim to manage hazardous fuels. An authorized wildfire prevention project involves measures developed by the Secretary concerned for hazardous fuels reduction, forest health, restoration, watershed restoration, and habitat protection for threatened and endangered species in at-risk forests. "Threatened and endangered species habitat" refers to Federal land where natural fire regimes are important or wildfire is a threat. AUTHORIZED WILDFIRE PREVENTION PROJECTS. The Secretary shall implement wildfire prevention projects in at-risk forests and endangered species habitat, focusing on reducing surface, ladder, and canopy fuels. Protection from catastrophic wildfires is a priority for endangered species habitat projects. Authorized wildfire prevention projects on threatened and endangered species habitat must enhance protection from wildfires for the species or habitat and comply with guidelines in the species recovery plan under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. In at-risk forests, authorized wildfire prevention projects aim to improve Federal land conditions from class II or III to class I. Grazing of domestic livestock may be permitted in certain cases. Authorized wildfire prevention projects in at-risk forests aim to improve Federal land conditions from class II or III to class I. Timber harvesting and thinning are also permitted to reduce wildfire risks. Authorized wildfire prevention projects can use domestic livestock grazing to reduce fuel loads and recover burned areas. Timber harvesting and thinning are allowed to prevent wildfires, without requiring revisions to land management plans. It also addresses the consideration of public petitions for designating federal land as at-risk forest or endangered species habitat. The Secretary must review and make a determination on public petitions for designating Federal land as at-risk forest or endangered species habitat within 60 days of receiving them. SEC. 5. PUBLIC REVIEW AND ENVIRONMENTAL ANALYSIS. The Secretary must publish a notice of proposed wildfire prevention projects in the Federal Register for public comment.
